summary: This document is an email chain among prosecutors discussing a draft protective order for discovery in the US v. Epstein case. The debate centers on whether to allow the defendant (Jeffrey Epstein) to review sensitive discovery materials only in the presence of counsel or not at all, with concerns about defense preparation and security.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as the defendant in the criminal case US v. Epstein; the protective order debate concerns whether he can be shown sensitive discovery materials, potentially only during meetings with counsel at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Draft Protective Order Circulated
events.description: A draft protective order for discovery in US v. Epstein is shared among the prosecution team, highlighting a section that would prevent sensitive materials from being shown to the defendant at all.

events.title: Updated Protective Order Drafted
events.description: An updated version of the protective order is prepared with cosmetic edits and slight additional protections, to be sent to chiefs after review.

events.title: Email Discussion on Protective Order
events.description: Prosecutors exchange emails debating whether to modify the protective order to allow the defendant to review sensitive discovery materials in the presence of counsel, balancing defense preparation needs against security concerns.

keyFacts: Prosecutors are drafting a protective order for discovery in the US v. Epstein case (docket 2018R01618).
A key debate is whether Jeffrey Epstein can be shown sensitive discovery materials at all, or only during meetings with his counsel at MCC.
One prosecutor argues for allowing review in counsel's presence to avoid defense complaints about inadequate preparation.
The document indicates the prosecution team's internal coordination and consideration of procedural safeguards.
The correspondence shows the case was active in July 2019, with discovery materials being managed under protective orders.
